resources.string: This app features calculators for both standard color-band resistors, capable of converting between color to value and value to color, as well as SMD resistors with three different code standards for determining resistance.

This app follows the IEC 60062 and IEC 60063 international standards for resistor coding and calculations to help ensure accuracy. For more detailed information, you can refer to the IEC 60062/60063 pages below.
Rate this app on Google Play
The entered resistance value is part of the %1$s series.
Your value is not in the E-series
With the selected tolerance, the closest E-series value is %1$s.
Adjust your selection to match the supported tolerances for a %1$s-band resistor.

The resistor color code uses colored bands to indicate resistance value, tolerance, and sometimes the temperature coefficient of resistors. This system allows for easy identification of resistor values in a compact format.
Each color corresponds to a specific value, depending on its position on the resistor. The standard colors and their corresponding values are displayed in the table below.
Three-band resistors have two significant figure bands and one multiplier band. If the tolerance is not indicated, it is typically assumed to be ±20%.
Four-band resistors are the most common type. They have two significant figure bands, one multiplier band, and one tolerance band, which is typically larger than the other bands.
Five-band resistors are used for higher precision. They have three significant figure bands, one multiplier band, and one tolerance band. These resistors are sometimes blue.
Six-band resistors include a temperature coefficient band in addition to the five-band code, indicating how the resistance changes with temperature.
"Green (5), Blue (6), Black (0), Brown (×10), Red (±2%), Brown (100 ppm/°C)"

The IEC 60062 standard defines code markings for resistors. It uses alphanumeric codes to represent resistance values in a compact format, making it suitable for marking small components, such as SMD (Surface-Mount Device) resistors.
SMD resistors use different coding systems based on the number of digits or characters used. The most common coding standards are:
The three-digit code is similar to the resistor color code system. The first two digits represent the significant figures, and the third digit is the multiplier. The equation is:
The four-digit code is used for high-precision resistors. The first three digits represent the significant figures, and the fourth digit is the multiplier. The equation is:
"The letter 'R' indicates the position of the decimal point for resistance values lower than 10 \u03A9. For example, 0R5 would be 0.5 \u03A9 and 0R01 would be 0.01 \u03A9."

The EIA-96 code is a two-digit code followed by a letter, used for precision resistors with 1% tolerance. The two digits represent a value in the E96 series, while the letter indicates the multiplier. For example:
"'43' corresponds to 274 \u03A9, while 'C' indicated a multiplier of \u00D7100. Thus, 274 \u00D7 100 = 27,400 \u03A9."
The multiplier indicates the factor by which to multiply the significant figures. In the EIA-96 code, letters represent multipliers as follows:

"These are the common resistance value codes, but a manufacturer may use a variation on these or even something completely different. It is therefore always important to verify the manufacturer's marking system."

"The standardization of resistor values, known as 'preferred values' or the 'E-series,' simplifies mass production and stock management by spacing resistance values approximately equally on a logarithmic scale. This approach allows manufacturers to limit the number of different values they need to produce."

The E-series is a set of preferred resistor values, organized by levels of precision. Each E-series is represented by a number (E-6, E-12, E-24, etc.), indicating the number of values per decade (1–10, 10–100, etc.). The more values in an E-series, the more precise the resistor selection. The values can be calculated using the following equation:
The E-6 series is typically used for 3-band resistors, offering less precision.
The E-12 and E-24 series are used for 4-band resistors, providing better precision.
The E-48, E-96, and E-192 series are used for 5 and 6-band resistors, providing high precision with tolerances as low as 0.05%. These series also introduce a third significant digit.

The information provided here regarding IEC standards is intended for general guidance. Please note that not all components may strictly adhere to these standards, as manufacturers may have variations or different interpretations. Always consult the specific datasheet or contact the manufacturer directly if you are unsure about the specifications or standards for a particular component.
